revised_title: Impact Tests on Polymers: Crack-Blunting Mechanisms and Thermal Effects
tldr: This study investigates the crack-blunting mechanisms in impact tests on three different polymers: high-density polyethylene (HDPE), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), and polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA). The authors found that the fracture toughness of these polymers is highly dependent on the strain rate and temperature. They propose a thermal diffusion-controlled process as the most likely cause of the observed rate dependence, which leads to crack-tip blunting and increased fracture toughness.
